name: NPR
text:
Protesters in Belarus' capital took to the streets in large numbers Sunday for the fifth weekend in a row, calling for the country's authoritarian president to resign. Demonstrations also took place in 16 other cities across the country.
https://t.co/MwLjENpGdk

name: NPR
text:
Book Review: Sophie Yanow's new graphic novel chronicles her time studying abroad in Paris. It's not suspenseful or eventful, but Yanow's combination of perception and humility makes for an engaging read.
https://t.co/TETfFMn7RX

name: NPR
text:
Actress Sarah Paulson says in writer-producer Ryan Murphy's world, "you better go big or go home." The duo takes a visit to an asylum together once again in "Ratched," which drops on Netflix this week. | @hereandnow 
https://t.co/VoacdgQu5M

name: NPR
text:
Latino USA host Maria Hinojosa has spent her career covering those silenced in the media. Now she's telling her own story in a new memoir.

"We all have to work at making the immigrant story much more public," she says.
https://t.co/AIjAEUmCqF

name: NPR
text:
"When the Light of the World Was Subdued, Our Songs Came Through" collects the work of more than 160 poets,  representing close to 100 indigenous nations. 

"A poem opens up time, it opens up memory, it opens up place," says Joy Harjo, U.S. Poet Laureate.
https://t.co/Ioo7np4rIN

name: NPR
text:
How do we help older people feel safe and comfortable — and happy — in these times?

• Write postcards every week
• Go for scenic drives
• Schedule virtual TV time
• Use family history as a topic for virtual lessons

See more ideas from our readers:
https://t.co/POohD3EXg5

name: NPR
text: The Army is working with private industry to create a coronavirus vaccine, but also working on its own. The military service has a history of creating vaccines and making medical breakthroughs. https://t.co/cIXbxPPigW
